Pneumonia.description: Pneumonia is a serious respiratory infection that causes inflammation in the air sacs (alveoli) of one or both lungs. These sacs may fill with fluid or pus (purulent material), causing cough with phlegm, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. It can range from mild to life-threatening and is most serious for infants, young children, people older than 65, and those with weakened immune systems or underlying health conditions.

Normal.info: The chest X-ray analysis suggests the lungs appear clear, with no distinct radiological signs typically associated with pneumonia. The lung fields show normal aeration, clear costophrenic angles, and no visible consolidations or infiltrates.
Normal.treatment_overview: No treatment specific to pneumonia is indicated. Maintain healthy lifestyle practices.

Pneumonia.info: The chest X-ray analysis indicates features (like opacities, consolidations, or infiltrates) that are consistent with pneumonia. Areas of increased density suggest fluid or inflammatory material in the lung tissue.
symptoms: Productive cough with phlegm (yellow, green, or bloody)
High fever (up to 105°F/40.5°C) with chills and rigors
Shortness of breath and rapid, shallow breathing
Sharp or stabbing chest pain that worsens with breathing or coughing
Confusion or altered mental status (especially in elderly)
Bluish lips or fingernails (cyanosis) in severe cases
causes: Bacterial: Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common), Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila, Mycoplasma pneumoniae
Viral: Influenza A and B, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19), Adenovirus, Rhinovirus, Parainfluenza
Fungal: Pneumocystis jirovecii (in immunocompromised), Histoplasma, Coccidioides, Aspergillus
Aspiration: Inhaling food, drink, vomit, or saliva into lungs
Risk factors: Smoking, chronic lung disease, weakened immune system, recent viral infection
Pneumonia.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on the type and severity of pneumonia. Bacterial pneumonia requires antibiotics, viral pneumonia may need antivirals or supportive care, and fungal pneumonia requires antifungal medications. Hospitalization may be needed for severe cases. **Always consult a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.**
diagnosis_methods: CT scan of chest (for detailed imaging)
prevention: Manage chronic conditions (diabetes, COPD, heart disease)
Avoid close contact with sick individuals

antivirals.name: Oseltamivir (Tamiflu)
antivirals.notes: For influenza pneumonia, start within 48 hours

corticosteroids.name: Dexamethasone
corticosteroids.notes: For severe COVID-19 pneumonia requiring oxygen

mild.description: Outpatient treatment, no signs of severe pneumonia

warning_signs: High fever >103°F (39.4°C) not responding to medication
Severe difficulty breathing or rapid breathing
Bluish discoloration of lips or fingertips

Brain Tumor.description: A brain tumor is an abnormal growth of cells within the brain or central spinal canal. Brain tumors can be primary (originating in the brain) or secondary/metastatic (spreading from other body parts). They are classified as benign (non-cancerous, slow-growing) or malignant (cancerous, aggressive). The location, size, and type of tumor determine symptoms and treatment options. Brain tumors can affect brain function by invading or compressing normal brain tissue.

glioma.info: Analysis of the MRI scan suggests features consistent with a glioma, a type of tumor arising from glial cells (supportive cells of the brain). Gliomas are classified into grades I-IV based on aggressiveness, with glioblastoma (grade IV) being the most aggressive. They represent about 30% of all brain tumors and 80% of malignant brain tumors.
symptoms: Vision problems (blurred, double vision, loss of peripheral vision)
Motor weakness on one side of body (hemiparesis)
causes: Genetic mutations (IDH1, IDH2, TP53, ATRX, EGFR, PTEN)
Prior radiation therapy to the head
Rare genetic syndromes: Neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, Turcot syndrome, Tuberous sclerosis
Family history of glioma (small increased risk)
Age: More common in older adults
Gender: Slightly more common in males
glioma.treatment_overview: Treatment varies based on tumor grade, location, size, and patient health. A multidisciplinary team (neurosurgeon, neuro-oncologist, radiation oncologist) develops an individualized treatment plan. Options include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and targeted therapies. **Requires specialized neuro-oncology care at a comprehensive cancer center.**
diagnosis_methods: Molecular testing (IDH mutation, MGMT methylation, 1p/19q codeletion)

chemotherapy.name: Temozolomide (Temodar)
chemotherapy.dosage: 75mg/m² daily during radiation, then 150-200mg/m² days 1-5 of 28-day cycle
chemotherapy.notes: Standard first-line chemotherapy for high-grade gliomas; oral medication

chemotherapy.name: Lomustine (CCNU)
chemotherapy.notes: Used for recurrent gliomas, often with other agents

chemotherapy.name: Procarbazine
chemotherapy.notes: Part of PCV regimen for oligodendrogliomas

chemotherapy.name: Gliadel Wafer
chemotherapy.dosage: Up to 8 wafers implanted during surgery
chemotherapy.notes: Carmustine wafers placed in tumor cavity

targeted_therapy.name: Tumor Treating Fields (TTFields/Optune)
targeted_therapy.notes: FDA-approved for glioblastoma; worn on shaved scalp

warning_signs: Sudden severe headache ('worst headache of life')
New onset seizures or status epilepticus
Severe confusion or loss of consciousness

meningioma.info: Analysis of the MRI scan suggests features consistent with a meningioma, a tumor arising from the meninges (protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord). Meningiomas are the most common primary brain tumors, representing about 37% of all brain tumors. Most (90%) are benign (WHO Grade I), grow slowly, and are often found incidentally. They are more common in women and typically occur in adults over 40.
symptoms: Hearing loss or ringing in ears (tinnitus)
Progressive weakness in arms or legs
causes: Previous ionizing radiation to the head
Hormonal factors (more common in women, may grow during pregnancy)
Genetic mutations (NF2, AKT1, SMO, TRAF7, KLF4)
meningioma.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on tumor size, location, grade, symptoms, and patient health. Small, asymptomatic meningiomas may be monitored with regular MRI. Symptomatic or growing tumors require intervention. Options include surgery, radiation therapy (including stereotactic radiosurgery), and rarely medical therapy. **Requires specialized neurosurgical evaluation.**
diagnosis_methods: MRI with and without contrast (gold standard)

chemotherapy.name: Hydroxyurea
chemotherapy.notes: For unresectable recurrent meningiomas; modest benefit

grade_I.name: Benign Meningioma
grade_I.prognosis: Excellent; often cured with complete resection
grade_I.treatment: Surgery or observation; radiosurgery if unresectable

warning_signs: Rapid vision changes or vision loss
Difficulty walking or loss of balance
Increasing drowsiness or loss of consciousness

notumor.info: The MRI scan analysis does not show clear radiological signs indicative of a brain tumor. The brain parenchyma appears normal without evidence of mass lesions, abnormal enhancement, midline shift, or hydrocephalus. Normal anatomical structures are preserved.
notumor.treatment_overview: No tumor-specific treatment indicated. If neurological symptoms persist, further evaluation for other causes may be warranted.
recommendations: Report any new neurological symptoms promptly
Follow up with primary care physician
Consider baseline MRI for future comparison if indicated

pituitary.info: Analysis of the MRI scan suggests features consistent with a pituitary tumor (pituitary adenoma). Pituitary adenomas arise from the pituitary gland at the base of the brain and are almost always benign. They are classified as functioning (hormone-secreting) or non-functioning, and by size: microadenomas (<10mm) or macroadenomas (≥10mm). They represent about 10-15% of all brain tumors.
symptoms: - Prolactinoma: Irregular periods, infertility, milk discharge, erectile dysfunction
- Growth hormone-secreting: Acromegaly (enlarged hands/feet/face), joint pain
- ACTH-secreting: Cushing's disease (weight gain, moon face, thin skin, diabetes)
- TSH-secreting: Hyperthyroidism (weight loss, rapid heart, sweating)
Pituitary apoplexy (sudden bleeding): Severe headache, vision loss, hormone crisis
causes: Generally not associated with environmental factors
pituitary.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on tumor type, size, hormone production, and symptoms. Prolactinomas are usually treated medically. Other types may require surgery (transsphenoidal approach), radiation therapy, or medical management. **Requires multidisciplinary care from endocrinologist, neurosurgeon, and neuro-ophthalmologist.**
diagnosis_methods: Comprehensive hormone blood tests (prolactin, GH, IGF-1, cortisol, ACTH, TSH, FSH, LH, testosterone/estrogen)
MRI of pituitary with contrast (gold standard)
Inferior petrosal sinus sampling (for ACTH adenomas)
prevention: Genetic testing and counseling for hereditary syndromes
Regular monitoring if predisposing syndrome present
Early reporting of hormonal or visual symptoms

prolactinoma.name: Cabergoline (Dostinex)
prolactinoma.duration: Long-term; may attempt discontinuation after 2+ years
prolactinoma.notes: First-line for prolactinoma; shrinks tumor, normalizes prolactin

prolactinoma.name: Bromocriptine (Parlodel)
prolactinoma.notes: Older dopamine agonist; more side effects; safe in pregnancy

acromegaly.name: Pasireotide (Signifor LAR)
acromegaly.notes: For resistant cases; higher diabetes risk

acromegaly.name: Pegvisomant (Somavert)
acromegaly.notes: GH receptor antagonist; for resistant cases

non_functioning.treatment: Surgery if symptomatic; observation if not

gh_secreting.treatment: Surgery first-line; medical therapy if needed

warning_signs: Sudden vision loss or double vision
Signs of adrenal crisis (weakness, hypotension, confusion)
These may indicate pituitary apoplexy - MEDICAL EMERGENCY

Malaria.description: Malaria is a life-threatening parasitic disease caused by Plasmodium parasites, transmitted to humans through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. There are five species that infect humans: P. falciparum (most deadly), P. vivax (most widespread), P. malariae, P. ovale, and P. knowlesi. Malaria causes cycles of fever, chills, and flu-like illness. Without prompt treatment, P. falciparum malaria can progress to severe illness and death within 24 hours.

Uninfected.info: Analysis of the blood cell image suggests no visible malaria parasites within the red blood cells. The cells appear normal in morphology without evidence of ring forms, trophozoites, schizonts, or gametocytes.
Uninfected.treatment_overview: No malaria treatment indicated. If symptoms suggestive of malaria persist, repeat testing may be warranted.
prevention: Wear long sleeves and pants, especially after dusk
Take antimalarial prophylaxis when traveling to endemic areas
Use screens on windows and doors

Parasitized.info: Analysis of the blood cell image shows features consistent with the presence of malaria parasites within red blood cells. Visible features may include ring-form trophozoites, mature trophozoites, schizonts, or gametocytes depending on the parasite stage and species.
symptoms: Cyclical fever pattern (every 48-72 hours depending on species)
causes: Plasmodium falciparum (most severe, highest mortality, Sub-Saharan Africa)
Plasmodium vivax (most widespread, can cause relapses)
Plasmodium ovale (similar to vivax, West Africa)
Transmission: Bite of infected female Anopheles mosquito
Other routes: Blood transfusion, organ transplant, shared needles, congenital (mother to fetus)
Risk factors: Travel to endemic areas, lack of immunity, pregnancy, young children, HIV/AIDS
Parasitized.treatment_overview: Malaria requires prompt treatment with antimalarial medications. Treatment choice depends on the species, severity, and local drug resistance patterns. Severe malaria requires IV medications and ICU care. **Malaria is a MEDICAL EMERGENCY - seek immediate care. Delays can be fatal.**
diagnosis_methods: Microscopic examination of Giemsa-stained blood smear (gold standard)
Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) - detect parasite antigens
prevention: DEET, picaridin, or IR3535 repellent on exposed skin
Protective clothing (long sleeves, pants) after dusk
RTS,S/AS01 vaccine (Mosquirix) for children in endemic areas

uncomplicated_falciparum.name: Artemether-Lumefantrine (Coartem)
uncomplicated_falciparum.dosage: Weight-based dosing, 6 doses over 3 days (e.g., 4 tablets per dose for >35kg)
uncomplicated_falciparum.notes: First-line ACT; take with fatty food for absorption

uncomplicated_falciparum.name: Dihydroartemisinin-Piperaquine (Eurartesim)
uncomplicated_falciparum.notes: Alternative ACT; avoid if cardiac conduction issues

severe_malaria.name: Artesunate IV/IM
severe_malaria.duration: Until oral tolerated (minimum 24h), then complete with oral ACT
severe_malaria.notes: FIRST-LINE for severe malaria; reduces mortality vs quinine

severe_malaria.name: Quinine IV
severe_malaria.duration: Until oral tolerated, then complete with oral therapy
severe_malaria.notes: Alternative if artesunate unavailable; monitor cardiac rhythm

vivax_ovale.name: Chloroquine
vivax_ovale.notes: Still effective for P. vivax/ovale (except resistant areas)

vivax_ovale.name: Primaquine (radical cure)
vivax_ovale.notes: REQUIRED to prevent relapse; check G6PD first (hemolysis risk)

vivax_ovale.name: Tafenoquine (Krintafel)
vivax_ovale.notes: Alternative for radical cure; requires G6PD testing

prophylaxis.name: Atovaquone-Proguanil (Malarone)
prophylaxis.timing: 1-2 days before, during, 7 days after travel

prophylaxis.name: Doxycycline
prophylaxis.timing: 1-2 days before, during, 28 days after travel
prophylaxis.notes: Inexpensive; may cause photosensitivity; avoid in pregnancy/children <8

prophylaxis.name: Mefloquine (Lariam)
prophylaxis.timing: 2-3 weeks before, during, 4 weeks after travel
prophylaxis.notes: Weekly dosing; avoid if psychiatric history, seizures, cardiac issues

prophylaxis.name: Chloroquine
prophylaxis.timing: 1-2 weeks before, during, 4 weeks after travel

prophylaxis.name: Tafenoquine (Arakoda)
prophylaxis.dosage: 200mg daily x3 days loading, then 200mg weekly
prophylaxis.timing: Weekly during and 1 week after travel

supportive.name: Acetaminophen
supportive.notes: For fever and pain; avoid aspirin/ibuprofen (platelet issues)

supportive.name: Dextrose (Glucose)
supportive.notes: For hypoglycemia (common with quinine and severe malaria)

supportive.name: Benzodiazepines
supportive.notes: For seizure management in cerebral malaria

supportive.name: Exchange Transfusion
supportive.notes: Consider for parasitemia >10% with severe complications

uncomplicated.criteria: Symptomatic malaria without signs of severity or vital organ dysfunction
uncomplicated.treatment: Oral ACT, outpatient if reliable follow-up

severe.criteria: One or more: impaired consciousness, prostration, multiple convulsions, respiratory distress, shock, pulmonary edema, abnormal bleeding, jaundice, severe anemia (Hb <5g/dL), hypoglycemia (<40mg/dL), acidosis, renal impairment, hyperparasitemia (>10%)
severe.treatment: IV artesunate, ICU care, supportive management

warning_signs: Severe vomiting (unable to take oral medication)

Tuberculosis.description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a serious infectious disease caused primarily by Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It typically attacks the lungs (pulmonary TB) but can also affect other parts of the body (extrapulmonary TB). TB spreads through the air when infected individuals cough, sneeze, or spit. About one-quarter of the world's population has latent TB (infected but not sick). Active TB disease develops in 5-10% of infected people, usually within 1-2 years. TB is curable with proper treatment.

Normal.info: The chest X-ray analysis suggests the lungs appear clear, without radiological signs typically associated with active pulmonary tuberculosis. No cavities, infiltrates, nodules, pleural effusions, or lymphadenopathy are noted.
Normal.treatment_overview: No active TB treatment indicated. Consider evaluation for latent TB if high-risk exposure.
prevention: BCG vaccination (primarily for children in endemic areas)
Prompt treatment of active TB cases
Treatment of latent TB in high-risk individuals

Tuberculosis.info: The chest X-ray analysis shows features that can be consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis, such as upper lobe infiltrates, cavitary lesions, nodules, fibrosis, calcifications, or pleural effusions. Confirmation requires microbiological testing.
symptoms: Persistent cough lasting 3 or more weeks
Coughing up blood or blood-tinged sputum (hemoptysis)
Chest pain with breathing or coughing
causes: Transmission: Airborne droplets from active pulmonary TB
Risk factors for infection: Close contact with active TB, crowded living conditions, healthcare work, prisons, homeless shelters
Risk factors for progression to active disease:
Tuberculosis.treatment_overview: Active TB requires a combination of antibiotics for 6-9+ months to prevent drug resistance. Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) is recommended to ensure adherence. Drug-resistant TB requires longer treatment with specialized regimens. Latent TB is treated to prevent progression. **Complete the entire course of medication - stopping early leads to drug resistance and treatment failure.**
diagnosis_methods: Symptom history and TB exposure history
Interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs): QuantiFERON-TB Gold, T-SPOT.TB
Sputum culture on Löwenstein-Jensen or liquid media (gold standard)
GeneXpert MTB/RIF (rapid molecular test, detects rifampin resistance)
prevention: BCG vaccination (for children in endemic areas; limited efficacy in adults)
Early detection and treatment of active cases
UV germicidal irradiation in healthcare facilities
Respiratory isolation for active pulmonary TB

first_line.name: Isoniazid (INH)
first_line.notes: Bactericidal; take pyridoxine (B6) 25-50mg daily to prevent neuropathy

first_line.name: Rifampin (Rifampicin)
first_line.notes: Bactericidal; turns urine/tears orange; many drug interactions

first_line.name: Pyrazinamide
first_line.notes: Sterilizing activity; monitor uric acid, liver function

first_line.name: Ethambutol
first_line.notes: Added until drug susceptibility known; monitor vision (optic neuritis)

mdr_tb.name: Bedaquiline
mdr_tb.notes: Core drug for MDR-TB; QT prolongation risk

mdr_tb.name: Pretomanid
mdr_tb.notes: Part of BPaL regimen for XDR-TB

mdr_tb.name: Linezolid
mdr_tb.notes: Core drug; monitor for myelosuppression, neuropathy

mdr_tb.name: Cycloserine
mdr_tb.notes: CNS side effects; give with pyridoxine

supportive.name: Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6)
supportive.notes: Prevents isoniazid-induced neuropathy; essential in pregnancy, diabetes, HIV, malnutrition

supportive.name: Acetaminophen
supportive.notes: For fever and pain; use cautiously with liver toxicity

supportive.name: Prednisone
supportive.notes: For TB meningitis, pericarditis, severe pleural effusion

hiv_coinfection.name: Antiretroviral Therapy (ART)
hiv_coinfection.timing: Start within 2-8 weeks of TB treatment
hiv_coinfection.notes: Rifampin interacts with many ARVs; may use rifabutin instead

hiv_coinfection.name: Rifabutin
hiv_coinfection.notes: Alternative to rifampin; fewer drug interactions with ARVs

laboratory: Baseline: CBC, CMP, LFTs, HIV test, HBV/HCV
Sputum smear/culture at 2 months (should convert to negative)
Monthly LFTs if risk factors for hepatotoxicity
Visual acuity and color vision (monthly if on ethambutol)
Drug susceptibility testing if culture-positive at 2 months

warning_signs: Persistent nausea/vomiting for more than 3 days
Fever lasting more than 3 days after starting treatment

drug_resistance.polydrug_resistant: Resistant to more than one first-line drug (but not both INH and rifampin)
drug_resistance.mdr_tb: Multidrug-resistant: resistant to at least isoniazid AND rifampin
drug_resistance.pre_xdr_tb: MDR-TB plus resistance to any fluoroquinolone
drug_resistance.xdr_tb: Pre-XDR plus resistance to bedaquiline and/or linezolid

Dental.description: Dental conditions encompass a wide range of issues affecting the teeth, gums, and oral cavity. Common conditions include cavities (dental caries), gum disease (periodontal disease), impacted teeth (often wisdom teeth), and various dental restorations and replacements. Regular dental care is essential for preventing and managing these conditions. Dental X-rays help identify issues not visible during routine examination.

cavity.info: Analysis indicates features consistent with a dental cavity (dental caries). Cavities appear as areas of radiolucency (darker areas) on X-rays, indicating demineralization and destruction of tooth structure. They can occur on chewing surfaces, between teeth, or at the root surface.
symptoms: Toothache (spontaneous pain or pain with triggers)
Sensitivity to hot, cold, or sweet foods/drinks
Visible holes or pits in teeth
Brown, black, or white staining on tooth surface
Swelling near affected tooth (if abscess develops)
causes: Frequent consumption of sugary foods and drinks
Dry mouth (xerostomia) from medications, medical conditions, or radiation
cavity.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on cavity severity. Early cavities may be reversed with fluoride. Established cavities require removal of decay and restoration. Deep cavities may need root canal treatment. Severely damaged teeth may require extraction. **Consult a dentist promptly to prevent progression.**
prevention: Brush teeth twice daily with fluoride toothpaste
Dental sealants for molars (especially in children)
Consider prescription fluoride for high-risk patients

fluoride_treatments.name: Fluoride Varnish (Duraphat)
fluoride_treatments.notes: 5% sodium fluoride; prevents and may reverse early decay

fluoride_treatments.name: Fluoride Gel/Foam
fluoride_treatments.notes: Applied in dental office via tray

remineralization.name: Casein Phosphopeptide-ACP (MI Paste)
remineralization.notes: Delivers calcium and phosphate for remineralization

pain_management.name: Clove Oil (Eugenol)
pain_management.usage: Apply small amount to affected tooth

antibiotics.name: Metronidazole
antibiotics.notes: For anaerobic infections; often combined with penicillin

cavity_classification.class_I: Pits and fissures on occlusal surfaces
cavity_classification.class_II: Proximal surfaces of premolars and molars
cavity_classification.class_III: Proximal surfaces of incisors and canines (not involving incisal angle)
cavity_classification.class_IV: Proximal surfaces of incisors and canines involving incisal angle
cavity_classification.class_V: Cervical third of facial or lingual surfaces

warning_signs: Swelling of face, cheek, or jaw
Bad taste despite good oral hygiene

fillings.info: Analysis identifies existing dental fillings (restorations). Fillings appear as radiopaque (bright/white) areas on X-rays for amalgam or as more tooth-colored opacities for composite resins. Assessment includes checking for marginal integrity, secondary decay, and proper adaptation.
symptoms: Usually asymptomatic if in good condition
Rough or sharp edge felt with tongue
Visible crack or chip in filling
fillings.treatment_overview: Existing fillings should be monitored for integrity. Damaged, leaking, or worn fillings should be replaced. Recurrent decay under fillings requires removal of decay and new restoration. **Regular dental check-ups recommended every 6 months to monitor restorations.**
prevention: Avoid chewing ice or hard objects

desensitizing.name: Potassium Nitrate Toothpaste (Sensodyne)
desensitizing.notes: For sensitivity after filling placement or old fillings

desensitizing.name: Stannous Fluoride Toothpaste
desensitizing.notes: Helps with sensitivity and cavity prevention

desensitizing.name: Desensitizing Agent (Gluma, Super Seal)
desensitizing.notes: Applied in dental office for persistent sensitivity

amalgam.cons: Visible (silver color), mercury concerns, requires more tooth removal

composite_resin.pros: Aesthetic, bonds to tooth, less tooth removal
composite_resin.cons: May stain, less durable than amalgam, more expensive

gold.cons: Very expensive, highly visible, requires multiple visits

ceramic.cons: Expensive, brittle (can fracture), requires multiple visits

warning_signs: Persistent sensitivity lasting more than 2 weeks
Severe pain not relieved by over-the-counter medication

impacted tooth.info: Analysis suggests an impacted tooth — a tooth that hasn't erupted properly or is blocked from erupting into its normal position. Most commonly affects wisdom teeth (third molars), but can occur with canines or other teeth. May be partially or completely impacted.
symptoms: Pain or tenderness in gums or jaw
Swelling and redness of gums around the area
Jaw stiffness or difficulty opening mouth
Unpleasant taste when biting near the area
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
Crowding or shifting of adjacent teeth
Visible gum flap over partially erupted tooth
causes: Dense overlying bone or gum tissue
impacted tooth.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on symptoms and complications. Asymptomatic impacted teeth may be monitored. Symptomatic or problematic teeth typically require surgical extraction. Orthodontic treatment may be needed for impacted canines. **Consult dentist or oral surgeon for evaluation.**
diagnosis_methods: Assessment of adjacent tooth roots and nerves
prevention: Regular dental check-ups for early detection
Early extraction of problematic baby teeth if needed
Genetic counseling if family history present

pain_management.name: Ibuprofen
pain_management.notes: First-line for impacted tooth pain; anti-inflammatory

pain_management.name: Tramadol
pain_management.notes: For moderate to severe pain post-extraction

antibiotics.name: Clindamycin
antibiotics.notes: For penicillin allergy; good anaerobic coverage

antibiotics.name: Metronidazole
antibiotics.notes: Often combined with penicillin for severe infections

antiseptic_rinses.name: Warm Salt Water Rinse
antiseptic_rinses.usage: 1/2 teaspoon salt in 8oz warm water, rinse 3-4x daily

antiseptic_rinses.name: Hydrogen Peroxide Rinse
antiseptic_rinses.notes: Helps clean area around impacted tooth

post_surgical.name: Ice Packs
post_surgical.usage: 20 minutes on, 20 minutes off for first 24-48 hours

soft_tissue.description: Tooth covered only by gum tissue

horizontal.difficulty: Most difficult; may damage adjacent teeth

complications.pericoronitis: Infection of gum tissue around partially erupted tooth
complications.root_resorption: Damage to roots of adjacent teeth
complications.decay: Cavities in impacted or adjacent teeth

warning_signs: Severe pain not controlled by medication
Facial swelling extending to eye or neck
Numbness or tingling in lip, tongue, or chin

implant.info: Analysis identifies a dental implant — an artificial tooth root (typically titanium) surgically placed into the jawbone to support a crown, bridge, or denture. Implants integrate with bone (osseointegration) and provide a stable, long-term tooth replacement solution.
symptoms: Visible metal (if crown damaged or gum recession)
implant.treatment_overview: Dental implants require regular professional monitoring and excellent home care. Successful implants can last 15-25+ years or lifetime with proper maintenance. Complications like peri-implantitis require professional treatment. **Regular dental visits every 3-6 months essential for implant longevity.**
prevention: Use of interdental brushes or water flossers
Avoid smoking (major risk factor for failure)
Manage diabetes and other systemic conditions
Avoid hard/sticky foods that could damage crown

maintenance.name: Fluoride-free Toothpaste
maintenance.notes: Some sources recommend fluoride-free for titanium implants; consult dentist

peri_implantitis_treatment.name: Metronidazole
peri_implantitis_treatment.notes: Often combined with amoxicillin for anaerobic bacteria

implant_components.fixture: Titanium screw placed in bone (the implant proper)
implant_components.abutment: Connector piece between fixture and crown

success_factors.no_smoking: Non-smokers have 95%+ success vs 85-90% for smokers

early_failure.causes: Poor osseointegration, infection, poor bone quality
early_failure.treatment: Remove implant, bone graft, re-attempt later

late_failure.treatment: Treat infection, possible removal and replacement

mechanical_complications.description: Crown fracture, abutment loosening, screw fracture

warning_signs: Bleeding that doesn't stop with gentle cleaning
Bad odor or taste despite good hygiene
Crown becomes loose or falls off

maintenance_schedule.first_year: Check-ups at 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months post-placement
maintenance_schedule.after_first_year: Every 3-6 months depending on risk factors
maintenance_schedule.x_rays: Annual or biennial radiographs to monitor bone levels

Diabetic Retinopathy.description: Diabetic retinopathy is a diabetes complication that affects the eyes by damaging blood vessels in the retina. It's a leading cause of blindness in working-age adults. High blood sugar levels cause damage to retinal blood vessels, which can swell, leak, or close off completely. In advanced stages, new abnormal blood vessels grow on the retinal surface. Early detection and treatment can prevent or slow vision loss.

No DR.info: Analysis of the retinal fundus image suggests no visible signs of diabetic retinopathy. The retinal vessels appear normal, with no microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, or signs of neovascularization. The optic disc and macula appear healthy.
No DR.treatment_overview: No diabetic retinopathy treatment indicated. Focus on optimal diabetes control (HbA1c <7%), blood pressure control, and regular dilated eye exams annually.
monitoring: More frequent if diabetes poorly controlled

DR Present.info: Analysis of the retinal fundus image shows signs consistent with diabetic retinopathy. Features may include microaneurysms, dot-blot hemorrhages, hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA), or neovascularization. Severity requires assessment by an ophthalmologist to determine stage and treatment needs.
symptoms: Often asymptomatic in early stages (no symptoms)
Floaters (dark spots or strings floating in vision)
Dark or empty areas in vision
Sudden vision loss (if vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment)
Shadows or missing areas in field of vision
causes: Chronic high blood glucose levels (primary cause)
Duration of diabetes (longer duration = higher risk)
DR Present.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on severity and stage. Primary focus is strict diabetes control. Mild cases require monitoring. Moderate to severe cases may need laser photocoagulation, anti-VEGF injections, or surgery. **Requires regular monitoring by ophthalmologist with retina expertise. Vision loss can be prevented or slowed with timely treatment.**
prevention: Blood pressure control (<140/90, or <130/80 if tolerated)
- Type 1 diabetes: Within 5 years of diagnosis, then annually
- Type 2 diabetes: At diagnosis, then annually
Control other risk factors (kidney disease, obesity)
Pregnancy planning and close monitoring if diabetic

diabetes_control.name: Metformin
diabetes_control.notes: First-line for type 2 diabetes; improves insulin sensitivity

diabetes_control.name: Insulin (various types)
diabetes_control.notes: Essential for type 1, often needed in type 2; tight control reduces retinopathy risk

diabetes_control.name: SGLT2 Inhibitors (e.g., Empagliflozin, Dapagliflozin)
diabetes_control.notes: Reduces glucose, cardiovascular and kidney benefits

lipid_management.name: Statins (e.g., Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin)
lipid_management.notes: Lowers cholesterol; may have retinal benefits

lipid_management.name: Fenofibrate
lipid_management.notes: May slow diabetic retinopathy progression (FIELD and ACCORD studies)

intravitreal_injections.name: Bevacizumab (Avastin)
intravitreal_injections.notes: Anti-VEGF; off-label use; treats macular edema and proliferative DR

intravitreal_injections.name: Ranibizumab (Lucentis)
intravitreal_injections.notes: FDA-approved anti-VEGF for diabetic macular edema

steroid_injections.name: Triamcinolone Acetonide
steroid_injections.notes: For refractory macular edema; risk of cataract and glaucoma

oral_supplements.name: Vitamin D
oral_supplements.notes: May have protective retinal effects; maintain normal levels

mild_npdr.treatment: Optimize diabetes control, monitor every 6-12 months

moderate_npdr.description: Moderate Non-Proliferative DR: More than microaneurysms but less than severe
moderate_npdr.treatment: Optimize control, monitor every 3-6 months, consider treatment if macular edema

severe_npdr.description: Severe Non-Proliferative DR: Extensive hemorrhages, venous beading, IRMA
severe_npdr.treatment: Close monitoring every 2-4 months, consider panretinal photocoagulation (PRP)

pdr.description: Proliferative DR: Neovascularization of disc or elsewhere, vitreous hemorrhage
pdr.treatment: Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP), anti-VEGF injections, possible vitrectomy

dme.description: Diabetic Macular Edema: Retinal thickening involving macula

focal_laser.description: Treats specific leaking blood vessels in macula

grid_laser.description: Pattern of laser burns in macula for diffuse leakage

prp.description: Panretinal Photocoagulation: 1200-2000 laser spots in peripheral retina
prp.notes: Causes regression of abnormal blood vessels

monitoring_schedule.dme: 1-3 months, more frequent if active treatment

warning_signs: Sudden vision loss or severe blur
Complete loss of vision in one eye
lifestyle_modifications: Monitor blood glucose 3-4 times daily (type 1) or as recommended
LDL cholesterol <100 mg/dL (or <70 if cardiovascular disease)

Skin Cancer.description: Skin cancer is the uncontrolled growth of abnormal skin cells, most commonly caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight or tanning beds. It includes melanoma (the most dangerous type, arising from pigment-producing melanocytes) and non-melanoma types (basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma). Early detection is critical, especially for melanoma, as it can spread (metastasize) to other organs. Most skin cancers are curable if detected and treated early.

Benign.info: The skin lesion image appears consistent with benign (non-cancerous) features. Characteristics suggesting benignity include symmetrical shape, uniform color (typically one shade of brown/tan), smooth and well-defined borders, small size (<6mm), and stable appearance over time. Common benign lesions include normal moles (nevi), seborrheic keratoses, dermatofibromas, and skin tags.
symptoms: Uniform tan, brown, or flesh color
causes: Genetic factors (number and type of moles)
Sun exposure (can increase number of moles)
Benign.treatment_overview: No cancer-specific treatment indicated. Benign lesions generally require no treatment unless cosmetically concerning or causing irritation. Regular skin self-exams and periodic professional skin checks recommended. Monitor for any changes using the ABCDE rule. **If any changes occur, consult dermatologist promptly.**
prevention: Annual professional skin exam (or more frequent if high-risk)
Know your skin and personal/family history

monitoring.professional_exam: Annually, or every 3-6 months if high risk

abcde_rule.A: Asymmetry - one half doesn't match the other
abcde_rule.C: Color - varied shades of brown, black, tan, red, white, blue
abcde_rule.D: Diameter - larger than 6mm (pencil eraser), though melanomas can be smaller
abcde_rule.E: Evolving - changes in size, shape, color, or symptoms

when_to_see_dermatologist: Existing mole that changes (size, shape, color)
Mole that itches, bleeds, or becomes painful
'Ugly duckling' - one mole looks different from others
Personal or family history of melanoma
History of severe sunburns or tanning bed use

Malignant.info: The skin lesion image shows features consistent with malignant melanoma or high concern for skin cancer. Characteristics include asymmetry, irregular or poorly defined borders, multiple colors (brown, black, red, white, blue), diameter greater than 6mm, and/or evolving (changing) appearance. Melanoma can appear as a new dark spot or a changing mole. Early detection and treatment are critical for cure.
symptoms: New mole or growth appearing, especially after age 30
Existing mole that changes in size, shape, or color
Border that is irregular, scalloped, or poorly defined
Multiple colors within one lesion (brown, black, tan, red, white, blue, pink)
Diameter larger than 6mm (size of pencil eraser), though melanomas can be smaller
Evolution - any change in size, shape, color, elevation, or symptoms
Crusting or scabbing that doesn't heal
Satellite lesions (smaller spots near main lesion)
'Ugly duckling sign' - lesion looks different from other moles
causes: Fair skin, light hair, blue/green eyes (lower melanin protection)
Personal history of melanoma or other skin cancers
Age (risk increases with age, but can occur in young adults)
Malignant.treatment_overview: Treatment depends on melanoma type, stage (thickness/depth, lymph node involvement, metastasis), and location. Early-stage melanoma is usually cured with surgical excision. Advanced melanoma requires systemic therapy (immunotherapy, targeted therapy, chemotherapy) and possibly radiation. **Melanoma is life-threatening if not treated early - immediate dermatologist evaluation is critical.**
diagnosis_methods: Excisional biopsy (preferred - removes entire lesion with margin)
Shave biopsy (generally avoided for suspected melanoma - may not show depth)
Histopathological examination (Breslow thickness, Clark level, mitotic rate, ulceration)
Sentinel lymph node biopsy (for melanomas >0.8mm or high-risk features)
- MRI (brain if symptomatic or Stage III/IV)
prevention: - Broad-spectrum sunscreen SPF 30+ (apply generously, reapply every 2 hours)
- Wear protective clothing (long sleeves, wide-brimmed hat, UV-blocking sunglasses)
- Monthly skin self-exams (check entire body including scalp, nails, between toes)
- More frequent exams if high risk (every 3-6 months)
- Vitamin D from diet/supplements instead of sun exposure

surgical_treatment.name: Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB)
surgical_treatment.notes: Determines if cancer spread to lymph nodes

surgical_treatment.name: Lymph Node Dissection
surgical_treatment.indication: Positive sentinel node or clinically palpable nodes
surgical_treatment.notes: Complete removal of regional lymph nodes

immunotherapy.name: Pembrolizumab (Keytruda)
immunotherapy.dosage: 200mg IV every 3 weeks or 400mg every 6 weeks
immunotherapy.duration: Up to 1 year (adjuvant) or until progression (metastatic)
immunotherapy.notes: Anti-PD-1 antibody; first-line for advanced melanoma and high-risk adjuvant

immunotherapy.name: Nivolumab (Opdivo)
immunotherapy.dosage: 240mg IV every 2 weeks or 480mg every 4 weeks
immunotherapy.duration: Up to 1 year (adjuvant) or until progression
immunotherapy.notes: Anti-PD-1 antibody; approved for adjuvant and metastatic

immunotherapy.name: Ipilimumab (Yervoy)
immunotherapy.notes: Anti-CTLA-4 antibody; often combined with nivolumab

immunotherapy.name: Nivolumab + Ipilimumab Combination
immunotherapy.dosage: Nivolumab 1mg/kg + Ipilimumab 3mg/kg every 3 weeks x4, then Nivolumab alone
immunotherapy.notes: Superior efficacy but higher toxicity; for advanced melanoma

immunotherapy.name: High-Dose Interleukin-2 (IL-2)
immunotherapy.notes: Rarely used now; severe side effects; requires ICU

targeted_therapy.name: Dabrafenib (Tafinlar)
targeted_therapy.notes: BRAF V600E/K inhibitor; use with trametinib

targeted_therapy.name: Vemurafenib (Zelboraf)
targeted_therapy.notes: BRAF V600E inhibitor; monotherapy or with cobimetinib

targeted_therapy.name: Cobimetinib (Cotellic)
targeted_therapy.dosage: 60mg once daily, 21 days on/7 days off

targeted_therapy.name: Encorafenib (Braftovi)
targeted_therapy.notes: BRAF V600E/K inhibitor; combined with binimetinib

chemotherapy.name: Dacarbazine (DTIC)
chemotherapy.notes: Older chemotherapy; rarely used now (replaced by immunotherapy/targeted therapy)

chemotherapy.name: Temozolomide
chemotherapy.notes: Oral alternative to dacarbazine; can cross blood-brain barrier

chemotherapy.name: Paclitaxel + Carboplatin
chemotherapy.notes: For refractory disease after immunotherapy/targeted therapy

radiation_therapy.name: Adjuvant Radiation
radiation_therapy.indication: Positive margins, desmoplastic melanoma, extensive nodal disease
radiation_therapy.notes: After surgery to reduce local recurrence

radiation_therapy.name: Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS)
radiation_therapy.notes: Gamma Knife or CyberKnife for limited brain mets

radiation_therapy.name: Palliative Radiation
radiation_therapy.notes: For pain control and symptom relief

supportive_care.name: Prednisone
supportive_care.notes: For immune-related adverse events from immunotherapy

supportive_care.name: Doxycycline
supportive_care.notes: For acneiform rash from MEK inhibitors

superficial_spreading.description: Most common type; grows horizontally first, then vertically

nodular.description: Aggressive; grows vertically from onset; often dark blue-black

lentigo_maligna.description: Develops slowly from precursor lesion (lentigo maligna)

acral_lentiginous.description: Most common in darker-skinned individuals; palms, soles, under nails

amelanotic.description: Lacks pigment; appears pink/red; often misdiagnosed

stage_I.description: Thin melanoma <2mm, no lymph node spread

stage_II.description: Thicker melanoma (>1-4mm) or ulcerated, no lymph node spread
stage_II.treatment: Wide local excision, SLNB, consider adjuvant therapy

stage_III.description: Lymph node involvement or in-transit metastases
stage_III.treatment: Surgery + lymph node dissection, adjuvant immunotherapy or targeted therapy

stage_IV.description: Distant metastases (lungs, liver, brain, bone, distant skin)
stage_IV.treatment: Systemic therapy (immunotherapy, targeted therapy), surgery/radiation for select metastases

warning_signs: Mole that looks different from others ('ugly duckling')
Spread of pigment from border into surrounding skin
Appearance of lump or bump within a mole

follow_up_schedule.stage_0_I: Every 6-12 months for 5 years, then annually
follow_up_schedule.stage_II: Every 3-6 months for 2 years, then every 6-12 months for 3 years, then annually
follow_up_schedule.stage_III_IV: Every 3-4 months for 2 years, then every 6 months for 3 years, then annually
follow_up_schedule.imaging: CT or PET/CT every 3-12 months depending on stage and symptoms
